data.title: Replace "Mac OS" and "OS X" with "macOS"
data.body: OS X has been renamed to "macOS". More details [here](http://www.macworld.co.uk/news/mac-software/mac-os-sierra-x-10-12-fuji-features-uk-release-date-macos-touch-id-siri-apfs-wwdc-2016-3630374/).

data.title: Update font stack
data.body: Since Chrome 46 supports `BlinkMacSystemFont`, I think we should use it instead of  `.SFNSText-Regular` (also the private font is not working anymore on macOS Sierra).

data.title: Indexing never finishes when using `atom -a`
data.body:
### Prerequisites
- [x] Can you reproduce the problem in [safe mode](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#check-if-the-problem-shows-up-in-safe-mode)?
- [x] Are you running the [latest version of Atom](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#update-to-the-latest-version)?
- [x] Did you check the [debugging guide](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/)?
- [x] Did you check the [FAQs on Discuss](https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq)?
- [x] Are you reporting to the [correct repository](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#atom-and-packages)?
- [x] Did you [perform a cursory search](https://github.com/issues?q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom+-repo%3Aatom%2Felectron) to see if your bug or enhancement is already reported?

The only other mention of this bug I found was here https://github.com/atom/atom/issues/10286#issuecomment-216063073, but it seems that user didn't open an issue for it.
### Description

When adding a folder to an existing atom window with `atom -a [directory]`, Atom gets stuck indexing. That is, trying to open a file with `Cmd+P` will just show this:

![users rahat downloads temp 2016-06-17 19-55-45](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/3174006/16168161/874d70d8-34c5-11e6-98ac-f5bc84d1c14f.png)
### Steps to Reproduce
1. Setup minimal test case

``` sh
mkdir dir1 dir2
touch dir1/file1.txt dir2/file2.txt
```
1. Open first safe atom window (make sure atom isn't running at this point)

``` sh
atom --safe dir1
```

At this point, indexing works fine and you can use `Cmd+P` as expected.
1. Add a project to the window

``` sh
atom -a dir2
```

**Expected behavior:** For the indexing to finish and files of both projects to be searchable.

**Actual behavior:** The popup says `Indexing project...` forever, like in the above screenshot
### Versions

``` sh
atom --version
Atom    : 1.8.0
Electron: 0.36.8
Chrome  : 47.0.2526.110
Node    : 5.1.1
```

data.title: Don't test CSON.readFileSync behavior twice (here and in atom/season)
data.body:
Our build is failing on Janky with the following exception:

```
[26891:0615/122703:INFO:CONSOLE(87)] "Error: Cannot find module 'season/node_modules/cson-parser'
  at Module._resolveFilename (module.js:339:15)
  at Function.Module._resolveFilename (/private/var/lib/jenkins/workspace/atom/src/module-cache.coffee:273:20)
  at Function.Module._load (module.js:290:25)
  at Module.require (module.js:367:17)
  at require (/private/var/lib/jenkins/workspace/atom/src/native-compile-cache.js:50:27)
  at Object.<anonymous> (/private/var/lib/jenkins/workspace/atom/spec/compile-cache-spec.coffee:7:14)
  at Object.<anonymous> (/private/var/lib/jenkins/workspace/atom/spec/compile-cache-spec.coffee:1:1)
```

Which points at a problem with requiring a module's internal submodule in `compile-cache-spec.coffee`. Instead of relying on a `season` internal module, with this pull-request we simply verify that the CSON module gets called appropriately and avoid testing its caching/parsing behavior again in Atom (i.e. it's already tested in https://github.com/atom/season/blob/master/spec/cson-spec.coffee#L207).

I am not clear on why Janky cannot find that internal module (maybe npm got updated there and the module is now flattened?), but it felt reasonable to avoid this anti-pattern in the spec so that we can make it more bulletproof independently of which npm version our CI is running.

/cc: @atom/core

data.title: Ctrl+S
data.body: Every time I use Ctrl+S in Atom I get the message "The editor has crashed / Please report this issue [to this repository]". If I open the file again it actually does save the material, but this will be just a bit annoying until I can figure out a way to stop it from happening.

data.title: Pasting code with a comment block indents the pasted code too much
data.body:
Pasting code which contains a comment block, e.g.:

``` js
  /**
   * Comment
   */
```

is no longer being indented properly after pasting. Observe:

![ss](https://www.dropbox.com/s/uu8x9ugikvbkwis/comment%20indentation%20on%20paste.gif?dl=1)

Without the comment block:

![ss](https://www.dropbox.com/s/jcdaco4vyzabq7g/comment%20indentation%20on%20paste%202.gif?dl=1)

So the code is being indented one level too much.

Probably related to: https://github.com/atom/atom/issues/5362
Possibly also related to https://github.com/atom/atom/issues/7256, see comments about indentation @ https://github.com/atom/atom/issues/7256#issuecomment-224580507

Can we scoop up all these comment-block related issues and fix them up for one of the next Atom releases?

Atom version is 1.10.0-dev-f6e87b1.
I don't recall this being a problem in 1.9.x.

data.title: Make interactive package tests work with a top-level 'test' directory
data.body:
I realize this is vain, but I really hate the word "spec" and would like the option to just call them tests. That works fine when specifying paths on the command line, but the interactive runner was defaulting the path to `spec`. This allows `test` instead if no `spec` directory is present.

cc @as-cii @BinaryMuse

data.title: Can't type Chinese using Sogou Wubi on Mac
data.body:
When I upgrade Atom from 1.7.4 to 1.8.0,then I can type only one Chines word use Sogou input method(a Chinese keyboard layout).When I continue type Chinese word  then can't type anything.If change to English keyboard layout and type English text is ok.
I try Atom 1.9.0-beta0 version and have the same problem.But 1.7.4 version is work good.
My OS version is  OS X 10.11.5.

data.title: Dragging a tab outside atom should open that tab in a new window.
data.body: Shouldn't it? It's a cool feature i'm missing since I switched from sublime. I'm using Windows 10 btw.

data.title: word boundary not working with Unicode punctuations
data.body:
### Prerequisites

  none
### Description

Unicode punctuations used as word boundary is not working in Atom, 
     when specified  in Settings/Non Word Characters field
### Steps to Reproduce
1. open settings tab in Atom using `⌘ + ,`
2. navigate to `Non Word Characters` field
3. add `«` and `»`
4. new tab and input `what do you mean by«你太胖了»？`
5. double on `你太胖了` to select these chars enclosed by `«` and `»`,(what I expect) 
   but `by«你太胖了»？` selected instead

**Expected behavior:** [What you expected to happen]

 only `你太胖了` selected

**Actual behavior:** [What actually happened]

 `by«你太胖了»？` selected
### Versions

Atom    : 1.8.0
Electron: 0.36.8
Chrome  : 47.0.2526.110
## Node    : 5.1.1

apm  1.9.2
npm  2.13.3
node 0.10.40
python 2.7.10
## git 2.7.4

OS X El Capitan 10.11.5

data.title: FreeBsd (pcbsd) script/build ERROR
data.body:
hello , I tried to follow the guide to install PC-BSD on atom ( which is a derivative of freebsd ) but when I get to the point scripts / build # Creates application at $ TMPDIR / atom - build / Atom
I get these errors :
`
[oscar@oscar-pcbsd] ~/atom-master%   script/build
Node: v6.1.0
npm: v3.8.8
Installing build modules...
npm ERR! FreeBSD 10.3-RELEASE
npm ERR! argv "/usr/local/bin/node" "/usr/local/bin/npm" "--userconfig=/usr/home/oscar/atom-master/build/.npmrc" "install" "--loglevel" "error"
npm ERR! node v6.1.0
npm ERR! npm  v3.8.8
npm ERR! path /usr/home/oscar/.atom/.npm/registry.npmjs.org/asar/.cache.json.1497597207
npm ERR! code ENOENT
npm ERR! errno -2
npm ERR! syscall lstat

npm ERR! enoent ENOENT: no such file or directory, lstat '/usr/home/oscar/.atom/.npm/registry.npmjs.org/asar/.cache.json.1497597207'
npm ERR! enoent ENOENT: no such file or directory, lstat '/usr/home/oscar/.atom/.npm/registry.npmjs.org/asar/.cache.json.1497597207'
npm ERR! enoent This is most likely not a problem with npm itself
npm ERR! enoent and is related to npm not being able to find a file.
npm ERR! enoent 

npm ERR! Please include the following file with any support request:
npm ERR!     /usr/home/oscar/atom-master/build/npm-debug.log
`
**I also tried with elevated privileges:**
`[oscar@oscar-pcbsd] ~/atom-master% sudo script/build
Password:
Node: v6.1.0
npm: v3.8.8
Installing build modules...
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/usr/local/lib/node_modules/npm/node_modules/node-gyp/gyp/gyp_main.py", line 16, in <module>  
    sys.exit(gyp.script_main())

    return main(sys.argv[1:])

    return gyp_main(args)  
  File "/usr/local/lib/node_modules/npm/node_modules/node-gyp/gyp/pylib/gyp/**init**.py", line 514, in gyp_main  
    options.duplicate_basename_check)  
  File "/usr/local/lib/node_modules/npm/node_modules/node-gyp/gyp/pylib/gyp/**init**.py", line 130, in Load  
    params['parallel'], params['root_targets'])  
  File "/usr/local/lib/node_modules/npm/node_modules/node-gyp/gyp/pylib/gyp/input.py", line 2795, in Load  
    RemoveLinkDependenciesFromNoneTargets(targets)  
  File "/usr/local/lib/node_modules/npm/node_modules/node-gyp/gyp/pylib/gyp/input.py", line 1510, in RemoveLinkDependenciesFromNoneTargets  
    if targets[t].get('variables', {}).get('link_dependency', 0):  
KeyError: 'deps/breakpad/breakpad.gyp:dump_syms#target'  
gyp ERR! configure error  
gyp ERR! stack Error: `gyp` failed with exit code: 1  
gyp ERR! stack     at ChildProcess.onCpExit (/usr/local/lib/node_modules/npm/node_modules/node-gyp/lib/configure.js:305:16)  
gyp ERR! stack     at emitTwo (events.js:106:13)
gyp ERR! stack     at ChildProcess.emit (events.js:191:7)
gyp ERR! stack     at Process.ChildProcess._handle.onexit (internal/child_process.js:204:12)
gyp ERR! System FreeBSD 10.3-RELEASE
gyp ERR! command "/usr/local/bin/node" "/usr/local/lib/node_modules/npm/node_modules/node-gyp/bin/node-gyp.js" "rebuild"
gyp ERR! cwd /usr/home/oscar/atom-master/build/node_modules/minidump
gyp ERR! node -v v6.1.0
gyp ERR! node-gyp -v v3.3.1
gyp ERR! not ok 
npm ERR! FreeBSD 10.3-RELEASE
npm ERR! argv "/usr/local/bin/node" "/usr/local/bin/npm" "--userconfig=/usr/home/oscar/atom-master/build/.npmrc" "install" "--loglevel" "error"
npm ERR! node v6.1.0
npm ERR! npm  v3.8.8
npm ERR! code ELIFECYCLE

npm ERR! minidump@0.9.0 install: `node-gyp rebuild`

npm ERR!

npm ERR! Make sure you have the latest version of node.js and npm installed.

data.title: Atom freezing up when mouse not moving (Multiple monitor setup).
data.body:
### Description

Atom constantly freezing up when mouse is not moving on a multiple monitor setup. I.e.: When typing something it doesn't show up until mouse is moved on screen; Text cursor stops animating.

Only happens when atom is running on my main monitor. 
### Versions

Atom    : 1.8.0
Electron: 0.36.12
Chrome  : 47.0.2526.110
Node    : 5.1.1

apm  1.9.2
npm  2.13.3
node 0.10.40
python 3.5.1
git 2.8.3

OS:
Arch linux (using dwm tiling window manager)
### Edit

issue persists on many other applications, closed as it is not directly atom editor problem.

data.title: Save deletes pdf file
data.body:
### Description

Having my phd-thesis project opened in atom, and having compiled (latex) earlier, upon saving (cmd-s), the compiled pdf-file is deleted (sic! - not moved to trash) from the project folder.
### Steps to Reproduce
1. Clone the rep https://github.com/valentin-krasontovitsch/phd-thesis
2. Add project folder in atom
3. Open loday.tex
4. Hit your keyboard shortcut for save while in the editor pane or choose save from the file menu

**Expected behavior:**
Nothing (since no actual changes to file)

**Actual behavior:**
phd_thesis_krasontovitsch.pdf gets deleted
### Versions

Atom    : 1.8.0
Electron: 0.36.8
Chrome  : 47.0.2526.110
Node    : 5.1.1

OS X El Capitan Version 10.11.5

**NB** problem reproducable without any latex packages (more precisely: on clean install) installed, and in safe mode.

data.title: Crash on Open - Linux 14.04, Atom 1.8.0
data.body:
### Prerequisites
- [ Yes ] Can you reproduce the problem in safe mode?
- [ Yes ] Are you running the latest version of Atom?
- [ Yes ] Did you check the [debugging guide](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/)?
- [ Yes ] Did you check the [FAQs on Discuss](https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq)?
- [ Yes ] Are you reporting to the [correct repository](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#atom-and-packages)?
- [ Yes ] Did you [perform a cursory search](https://github.com/issues?q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom+-repo%3Aatom%2Felectron) to see if your bug or enhancement is already reported?

For more information on how to write a good [bug report](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#how-do-i-submit-a-good-bug-report) or [enhancement request](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#how-do-i-submit-a-good-enhancement-suggestion), see the `CONTRIBUTING` guide.
### Description

After updating a number of packages, Atom will not start. Not sure if they were due to a Chrome, Atom, or otherwise update.

There are no files in /tmp/Atom\ Crashes/
### Steps to Reproduce
1. Try to open atom

**Expected behavior:** [What you expected to happen]

Atom opens successfully, allows regular behavior.

**Actual behavior:** [What actually happened]

Window opens, showing "untitled - Atom" in the toolbar.
Alert popup says "The editor has crashed" "Please report this issue to https://github.com/atom/atom"
Option to close window, reload, keep it open.

Another variant, when trying to open:
$ atom --safe -f
App load time: 445ms
Failed to get crash dump id.
Report Id: 
### Versions

You can get this information from executing `atom --version` and `apm --version` at the command line. Also, please include the OS and what version of the OS you're running.

$ atom --version
Atom    : 1.8.0
Electron: 0.36.8
Chrome  : 47.0.2526.110
Node    : 5.1.1

$ apm --version
apm  1.9.2
npm  2.13.3
node 0.10.40
python 2.7.6
git 2.9.0

$ uname -a
Linux blah-desktop 3.13.0-88-generic #135-Ubuntu SMP Wed Jun 8 21:10:42 UTC 2016 x86_64 x86_64 x86_64 GNU/Linux

data.title: MouseWheel Scrolling Ignores Operating System Settings
data.body:
### Prerequisites
- [X] Can you reproduce the problem in [safe mode](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#check-if-the-problem-shows-up-in-safe-mode)?
- [X] Are you running the [latest version of Atom](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#update-to-the-latest-version)?
- [ ] Did you check the [debugging guide](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/)?
- [X] Did you check the [FAQs on Discuss](https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq)?
- [ ] Are you reporting to the [correct repository](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#atom-and-packages)?
- [X] Did you [perform a cursory search](https://github.com/issues?q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom+-repo%3Aatom%2Felectron) to see if your bug or enhancement is already reported?

For more information on how to write a good [bug report](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#how-do-i-submit-a-good-bug-report) or [enhancement request](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#how-do-i-submit-a-good-enhancement-suggestion), see the `CONTRIBUTING` guide.
### Description

The number of lines the mouse wheel scrolls does not correspond to the setting in the operating system.
### Steps to Reproduce
1. Open file in Atom
2. Scroll up and down with the mouse wheel

**Expected behavior:** [What you expected to happen]

The number of lines scrolled should be equal to the setting in the operating system.

**Actual behavior:** [What actually happened]

The number of lines scrolled gnores the operating system's setting.
### Versions

1.8

data.title: Inconsistency in keybindings configuration
data.body:
If I copy a keybinding from Preferences -> Keybindings and add it to my keymap.cson, Atom's behaviour should not change.  Here is an example where this doesn't hold.

Using Atom 1.8.0 with a fresh home folder just for this test (ATOM_HOME=...) on Ubuntu 14.04.

Create a new file, change the grammar from Plain Text to Python, and paste the following:

```
asdf = 0
as
```

Now place the cursor after the `as` on the 2nd line and type `d`.  The autocomplete offers `asdf` as the only suggestion.  Press tab.  `asdf` is autocompleted.

Now add to keymap.cson the following:

```
'atom-text-editor:not([mini])':
  'tab': 'editor:indent'
```

This exact binding (including the selector) was copied straight from Preferences -> Keybindings - search for "tab" and you will see it with source "Core".

Repeat the test - place the cursor after the `as`, type `d`, and press tab.  A tab is inserted.

data.title: Uncaught Error: ENOENT: no such file or directory, lstat '/Users/Nickismyname/Downloads/Atom.app'
data.body:

1. ...downloaded Atom, moved to Applications folder
2. ...wrote some text
